byline.contributor: Amie Tsang reported from Hong Kong, and Zhang Tiantian from Beijing. Charlotte Yang in Hong Kong contributed research.
byline.original: By AMIE TSANG and ZHANG TIANTIAN

abstract: China experiences downturn in number of marriages for second year in row, development many analysts say stems from years of one-child policy; fewer marriages in China has profound economic as well as social impact, as family-related purchases are on decline; some also point to concern younger generation made up of single people will not adhere to tradition of taking care of elderly parents.
lead_paragraph: The drop in marriage stems in part from China’s aging population, but also reflects that women who once were pushed to wed are exploring new options.
snippet: The drop in marriage stems in part from China’s aging population, but also reflects that women who once were pushed to wed are exploring new options....

headline.main: Marriage Falls in China, Transforming Finances and Families
headline.print_headline: As Fewer Wed, Effects Ripple Through China
